title: 104_hr3726
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Advancement of Women in the Science and Engineering Work Forces Act". The Congress acknowledges the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, citing higher rates of unemployment and underemployment for women compared to men. They recognize artificial barriers in recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in these fields, while also noting the importance of diversity in science and engineering workforces. The White House Task Force and Federal Coordinating Council initiatives have raised awareness about the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields and the need to eliminate barriers to their recruitment, retention, and advancement. Establishing a commission to address these issues would further emphasize the importance of promoting gender diversity in these workforces. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting gender diversity in science and engineering workforces by encouraging recruitment and retention programs for women. A commission called the "Commission on the Advancement of Women in the Science and Engineering Work Forces" is established to promote gender diversity in science and engineering workforces. The Commission's duty is to encourage recruitment and retention programs for women in these fields. The Commission will study the number of women in science and engineering fields, their underrepresentation in specific occupations, women's preparedness for careers and advancement, employer and union practices, opportunities and barriers for women's recruitment, retention, and advancement in academia, industry, and government. The Commission will examine the employment situations of women scientists and engineers compared to men, compile research on successful recruitment, retention, and advancement practices for women in science and engineering, and address other relevant issues as determined by the Commission. The Commission will issue recommendations for government, academia, and private industry to support the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in science and engineering. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various leaders in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various leaders in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy is among the appointees, who must meet specific qualifications related to diversity, business experience, and expertise in employment issues. Additionally, political affiliation is considered to ensure a balanced representation within the Commission. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives and the Senate, including the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members receive compensation based on the maximum rate of pay under section 5376 of title 5, United States Code. The Commission members engage in duties such as attending meetings and conferences, with travel expenses covered. Federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional compensation. A majority of members form a quorum, and the Chairperson is the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. The Technology Policy Chairperson leads the Commission, which must meet at least 5 times before completing reports. Additional meetings can be requested in writing. After the report in section 8(b), the Commission must meet at least once, but not more than twice for the report in section 8(c). Members not federal employees cannot receive additional compensation. The curr_chunk states that an officer or employee of the Federal Government is only considered an employee for specific purposes related to tort claims and compensation for work injuries. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, who will be paid at a specified rate. The Chairperson can appoint additional staff and determine their pay. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws, but their pay cannot exceed a certain limit. The Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate of basic pay. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is granted powers under Section 7. The Commission, under Section 7, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain official data from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises. The Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property to aid its work. It can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission may also contract with and compensate as provided in appropriations Acts. The Commission can contract with and compensate government and private agencies for research or surveys to carry out its duties under this Act. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission must submit a status report within 1 year of initial appointments, a recommendation report within 18 months, and a follow-up report as required. The Commission must submit a follow-up report before its termination, identifying implemented recommendations and providing additional information to the President and Congress. SEC. 9. CONSTRUCTION; USE OF INFORMATION OBTAINED.

    Non-Federal entities are not required to provide personnel policy information to the Commission, and any information obtained cannot be used in employment litigation.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION.

    The Commission will end one year after submitting the required report.

SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    Sums are authorized for fiscal years 1997-1999 to implement this Act.
